{{Use British English|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Paul Johnson | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE|size=100%}} | image = PaulJohnson1.jpg | caption = Johnson (right) being congratulated by [[Norman Francis]] and [[Ruth Johnson Colvin]] after receiving the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] in 2006 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1928|11|2|}} | birth_place = [[Manchester]], England | birth_name = Paul Bede Johnson | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = {{hlist | Journalist | popular historian}} | salary = | other_names = | known_for = Editor of the ''[[New Statesman]]'' (1965–70) | spouse = {{marriage|Marigold Hunt |1957}} | children = [[Daniel Johnson (journalist)|Daniel Johnson]]
[[Luke Johnson (businessman)|Luke Johnson]] | parents = | relatives = | education = [[Stonyhurst College]] | alma_mater = [[Magdalen College, Oxford]] | website = {{URL|http://pauljohnsonarchives.org}} }} '''Paul Bede Johnson''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE}} (born 2 November 1928) is an [[English people|English]] journalist, [[popular history|popular historian]], speechwriter, and author. While associated with the political left in his early career, he is now a conservative popular historian. Johnson was educated at the [[Jesuit]] independent school [[Stonyhurst College]], and at [[Magdalen College, Oxford]]. He first came to prominence in the 1950s as a journalist writing for and later editing the ''[[New Statesman]]'' magazine. A prolific writer, Johnson has written over 40 books and contributed to numerous magazines and newspapers. His sons include the journalist [[Daniel Johnson (journalist)|Daniel Johnson]], founder of ''[[Standpoint (magazine)|Standpoint]]'', and the businessman [[Luke Johnson (businessman)|Luke Johnson]], former chairman of [[Channel 4]]. == Early life and career == Johnson was born in [[Manchester]]. His father, William Aloysius Johnson, was an artist and Principal of the Art School in Burslem, [[Stoke-on-Trent]], [[Staffordshire]]. At [[Stonyhurst College|Stonyhurst]], Johnson received an education grounded in the [[Jesuit]] method,As he saw it in his 1957 "Conviction" essay. which he preferred over the more secularized curriculum of Oxford. Whilst at Oxford, Johnson was tutored by the historian [[A. J. P. Taylor]]{{Citation |first=Paul Bede |last=Johnson |title=Bugles softly blowing, national service was a time to treasure |journal=The Spectator |date=22 July 2000 |publisher=Find articles}}. and was a member of the exclusive [[Stubbs Society]]. After graduating with a [[British undergraduate degree classification#Second-Class Honours|second-class honours]] degree, Johnson performed his [[national service]] in the Army, joining the [[King's Royal Rifle Corps]] and then the [[Royal Army Educational Corps]], where he was [[Officer (military)|commissioned]] as a [[Captain (land)#Military and Air Force|Captain]] (acting) based mainly in [[Gibraltar]]. Here he saw the "grim misery and cruelty of the [[Francisco Franco|Franco]] regime".''Conviction'', p 206 Johnson's military record helped the Paris periodical ''Realités'' hire him, where he was assistant editor from 1952 to 1955. Johnson adopted a [[Left-wing politics|left-wing]] political outlook during this period as he witnessed, in May 1952, the police response to a riot in Paris, the "ferocity [of which] I would not have believed had I not seen it with my own eyes." (Communists were rioting over the visit of American general, [[Matthew Ridgeway]], who commanded the US Eighth Army during the [[Korean War]]; he had just been appointed Supreme Commander in Europe, and the Communists perceived him as anti-Communist.)[https://books.google.com/books?id=PUkgAGjIY0oC&pg=PA46&lpg=PA46&dq=may+1952+paris+riot+ridgeway&source=bl&ots=Mm10y0pYgj&sig=o7yJUKjJ5djX5eH8CLU5sh3fAlI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwic06ifh6LKAhVHRBQKHdC6CpUQ6AEIKDAF#v=onepage&q=may%201952%20paris%20riot%20ridgeway&f=false]. Then he served as the ''[[New Statesman]]''{{'}}s Paris correspondent. For a time, he was a convinced [[Bevanism|Bevanite]] and an associate of [[Aneurin Bevan]] himself. Moving back to London in 1955, Johnson joined the ''Statesman''{{'}}s staff. Some of Johnson's writing already showed signs of iconoclasm. His first book, about the [[Suez War]], appeared in 1957. An anonymous commentator in ''[[The Spectator]]'' wrote that "one of his [Johnson's] remarks about [[Hugh Gaitskell|Mr Gaitskell]] is quite as damaging as anything he has to say about Sir [[Anthony Eden]]", but the Labour Party's opposition to the Suez intervention led Johnson to assert "the old militant spirit of the party was back".[http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/25th-january-1957/7/i-rave-been-reading-paul-johnsons-suez-war-macgibb "A Spectator' Notebook"], ''The Spectator'', 25 January 1957, p.7 The following year, he attacked [[Ian Fleming]]'s [[James Bond]] novel ''[[Dr. No (novel)|Dr No]]''{{Citation |first=Paul Bede |last=Johnson |title=Sex, Snobbery and Sadism |journal=New Statesman |date=5 April 1958}}, in {{Citation |editor-first=Stephen |editor-last=Howe |title=Lines of Dissent: Writings from the "New Statesman" |place=London |publisher=Verso |year=1988 |pages=151–54}}. and in 1964 he warned of "The Menace of Beatlism"{{Citation |title=The Menace of Beatlism|journal=New Statesman |date=28 February 1964 |pages=326–27}}, reprinted as [http://www.newstatesman.com/culture/2014/08/archive-menace-beatlism "From the archive: The Menace of Beatlism"], ''New Statesman'', 28 August 2014 in an article contemporarily described as being "rather exaggerated" by [[Henry Fairlie]] in ''The Spectator''.Henry Fairlie [http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/6th-march-1964/4/beatles-and-babies "Beatles and Babies"], ''The Spectator'', 6 March 1964, p.4 He was successively lead writer, deputy editor and editor of the ''New Statesman'' magazine from 1965 to 1970. He was found suspect for his attendances at the soirées of [[Antonia Fraser|Lady Antonia Fraser]], then married to a [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] MP. There was some resistance to his appointment as ''New Statesman'' editor, not least from the writer [[Leonard Woolf]], who objected to a Catholic filling the position, and Johnson was placed on six months' probation.{{citation needed | date=May 2013}} ''Statesmen And Nations'' (1971), the anthology of his ''Statesman'' articles, contains numerous reviews of biographies of Conservative politicians and an openness to continental Europe; in one article Johnson took a positive view of events of [[May 1968 in France|May 1968]] in Paris, an article which at the time of first publication led Colin Welch in ''The Spectator'' to accuse Johnson of possessing "a taste for violence".Colin Welch [http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/31st-may-1968/31/imbecile-power "AfterThought: Imbecile Power"], ''The Spectator'', 30 May 1968, p.31 According to this book, Johnson filed 54 overseas reports during his ''Statesman'' years. == Shift rightward == In the 1970s, Johnson became increasingly [[Conservatism|conservative]] in his outlook and has largely remained so. In his ''Enemies of Society'' (1977), following a series of articles in the British press, he opposed the trade union movement, perceiving it as violent and intolerant, terming trade unionists "fascists". As Britain’s economy faltered, Johnson began to advocate the future British Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]]’s message of less government and less taxation. He was eventually won over to the Right and became one of Thatcher's closest advisers: "In the 1970s Britain was on its knees. The Left had no answers. I became disgusted by the over-powerful trade unions which were destroying Britain," he recalled in 2004.Jeremy Bradshaw [https://archive.is/20130129185332/http://www.newsmax.com/archives/articles/2004/6/29/165231.shtml "Paul Johnson: George Bush Is the Next Thatcher"], newsmax.com, 30 July 2004 After Thatcher's victory in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1979|general election of 1979]] Johnson advised on changes to [[legislation]] concerning [[trade unions]] and was also one of Thatcher's speechwriters. Johnson was quoted in 2004:
"I was instantly drawn to her," he recalls. "I'd known Margaret at Oxford. She was not a party person. She was an individual who made up her own mind. People would say that she was much influenced by [[Karl Popper]] or [[Frederick Hayek]]. The result was that Thatcher followed three guiding principles: truthfulness, honesty and never borrowing money."
From 1981 to 2009, Johnson wrote a column for ''[[The Spectator]]''; initially focusing on media developments, it subsequently acquired the title "And Another Thing". In his journalism, Johnson generally deals with issues and events which he sees as indicative of a general social decline, whether in art, education, religious observance or personal conduct. He has continued to contribute to the magazine, less frequently than before.[http://www.spectator.co.uk/search/author/?searchString=Paul%20Johnson Contributor: Paul Johnson], spectator.co.uk website During the same period he contributed a column to the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' until 2001. In a ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' interview in November 2003, he criticised the ''Mail'' for having a pernicious impact: "I came to the conclusion that that kind of journalism is bad for the country, bad for society, bad for the newspaper".Damian Thompson [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2003/11/03/ftjohn31.xml "'I'm very fond of that boy Tony'"], ''Daily Telegraph'', 3 November 2003 Johnson is a regular contributor to ''[[The Daily Telegraph]],'' mainly as a book reviewer, and in the [[United States of America|United States]] to ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[Commentary (magazine)|Commentary]]'' and the ''[[National Review]]''. He also writes for ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine.[http://search.forbes.com/search/colArchiveSearch?aname=Paul+Johnson&author=paul+and+johnson Contributor page: Paul Johnson], Forbes.com For a time in the early 1980s he wrote for ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' after [[Rupert Murdoch]] urged him to "raise its tone a bit".Paul Johnson [http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/29th-january-1994/21/and-another-thing "And Another Thing"], ''The Spectator'', 29 January 1994, p.21 Johnson is a critic of [[modernity]] because of what he sees as its [[moral relativism]],Paul Johnson [http://www.spectator.co.uk/columnists/all/3388016/and-another-thing.thtml "What the temptations on the high mountain mean today"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704133355/http://www.spectator.co.uk/columnists/all/3388016/and-another-thing.thtml |date=4 July 2010 }}, ''The Spectator'', 28 February 2009 and finds objectionable those who use [[Charles Darwin]]'s theory of [[evolution]] to justify their atheism or use it to promote biotechnological experimentation.Paul Johnson [http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/17th-october-1998/26/and-another-thing "And Another Thing – Shaping up for a new moral catastrophe in the 21st century"], ''The Spectator'', 16 October 1998, p.26 As a result, [[Richard Dawkins]] and [[Steven Pinker]] have been a target of Johnson's criticism.Paul Johnson [http://www.spectator.co.uk/columnists/14089/the-ayatollah-of-atheism-and-darwins-altars/ "The ayatollah of atheism and Darwin’s altars"], ''The Spectator'', 27 August 2005Paul Johnson [http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/31st-january-1998/22/and-another-thing "And Another Thing – An entertaining evening finding out how Professor Pinker's mind works"], ''The Spectator'', 31 January 1998, p.22 As a conservative Catholic, Johnson regards [[liberation theology]] as a [[heresy]] and defends [[clerical celibacy]], but departs from others in seeing many good reasons for ordination of women as priests.[http://archive.thetablet.co.uk/article/1st-august-1998/12/my-faith-in-women Paul Johnson, "My Faith in Women"], ''[[The Tablet]]'', 1 August 1998, p. 11 Admired by conservatives in the [[United States of America|United States]] and elsewhere, he is strongly [[anticommunist]].Paul Johnson, ''[[Modern Times: A History of the World from the 1920s to the 1980s|Modern Times]]'', ''passim'' Johnson has defended [[Richard Nixon]]Paul Johnson [http://www.commentarymagazine.com/article/in-praise-of-richard-nixon/ "In Praise of Richard Nixon"], ''Commentary'', 86:4, October 1988, p.50-53 in the [[Watergate]] scandal, finding his cover-up considerably less heinous than [[Bill Clinton]]'s [[perjury]] and [[Oliver North]]'s involvement in the [[Iran-Contra Affair]]. In his ''Spectator'' column, Johnson defended his friend [[Jonathan Aitken]],Paul Johnson [http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/28th-march-1998/19/and-another-thing "And Another Thing – The Aitken case: who is holding the scales of justice tilted?"], ''The Spectator'', 28 March 1998, p.19 has expressed admiration for General [[Augusto Pinochet]]"Pinochet remains a hero to me because I know the facts" (from ''Heroes'', cited by Richard Lourie [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/11/30/AR2007113000075.html "Heroes Are People, Too"], ''The Washington Post'', 2 December 2007 and (qualified) admiration for [[General Franco]].Paul Johnson [http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/13th-november-1999/38/and-another-thing "And Another Thing – Here is my list of the century's greatest political figures"], ''The Spectator'', 13 November 1999, p.38 Johnson was active in the campaign, led by [[Norman Lamont]], to prevent Pinochet's extradition to Spain after [[Augusto Pinochet's arrest and trial|Pinochet's arrest in London]]. "There have been countless attempts to link him to human rights atrocities, but nobody has provided a single scrap of evidence," Johnson was reported as saying in 1999.Nick Hopkins [https://www.theguardian.com/world/1999/jan/20/pinochet.chile "Rightwing fan club tinkers with Chile history"], ''The Guardian'', 20 January 1999 In ''Heroes'' (2008), Johnson returned to his longstanding claim that criticism of Pinochet's regime on human rights grounds came from "the Soviet Union, whose propaganda machine successfully demonised [Pinochet] among the chattering classes all over the world. It was the last triumph of the KGB before it vanished into history's dustbin".Paul Johnson [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-512714/She-crucified-enemies-burnt-London-ground-Meet-Britains-feminist-Boadicea.html "She crucified her enemies and burnt London to the ground. Meet Britain's first feminist, Boadicea"], ''Daily Mail'', 6 February 2008 [extracts from ''Heroes'' (2008)] He has described [[France]] as "a republic run by bureaucratic and party elites, whose errors are dealt with by strikes, street riots and blockades" rather than a democracy.Paul Johnson [https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2003/0721/029.html "Anti-Americanism Is Racist Envy"], ''Forbes'', 21 July 2003 He served on the Royal Commission on the Press (1974–77) and was a member of the Cable Authority (regulator) from 1984 to 1990. == Personal life == Paul Johnson has been married to the psychotherapist and former Labour Party parliamentary candidate Marigold Hunt, daughter of Dr. Thomas Hunt, physician to [[Winston Churchill]], [[Clement Attlee]] and [[Anthony Eden]], since 1958. They have three sons and a daughter: the journalist [[Daniel Johnson (journalist)|Daniel Johnson]],{{cite news|last=Popham|first=Peter|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/media-families-4-the-johnsons-1272087.html|title=Media families; 4. The Johnsons|work=The Independent|date=10 March 1997|accessdate=16 December 2017}} a freelance writer, editor of ''[[Standpoint (magazine)|Standpoint]]'' magazine, and previously associate editor of ''The Daily Telegraph,'' who is married to the writer and birth educator Sarah Johnson née Thompson; [[Luke Johnson (businessman)|Luke Johnson]], businessman and former chairman of Channel 4 Television; Sophie Johnson, who has worked in television drama; and Cosmo Johnson. Paul and Marigold Johnson have ten grandchildren. Marigold Johnson's sister, Sarah, an art historian, married the journalist, former diplomat and politician [[George Walden]]; their daughter, novelist [[Celia Walden]], is the wife of television presenter and former newspaper editor [[Piers Morgan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3240646/Marigold-Johnson-Boris-dad-MP-brother-law-husband.html|title=Marigold Johnson on Boris' dad, her MP brother-in-law and her husband|publisher=}} In 1998 it was revealed Johnson had an affair lasting eleven years with the writer Gloria Stewart.Elizabeth Grice [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/lifestyle/7800902/Paul-Johnson-After-70-you-begin-to-mellow.html "Paul Johnson: 'After 70 you begin to mellow'"], ''Daily Telegraph'', 4 June 2010 Stewart went public with the affair to the newspapers after what she saw as Johnson’s hypocrisy over his views on morality, religion and family values.Christopher Hitchens [http://www1.salon.com/media/1998/05/28media.html "The Rise and Fall of Paul "Spanker" Johnson"], ''salon'', [28 May 1998] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313132312/http://www1.salon.com/media/1998/05/28media.html |date=13 March 2012 }} Johnson is a friend of British playwright [[Tom Stoppard]], who dedicated his 1978 play ''[[Night and Day (play)|Night and Day]]'' to him. Johnson is a [[Watercolorist|watercolourist]], painting mainly landscapes, who has exhibited regularly. ==Honours== In 2006, Johnson was honoured with the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] by U.S. President [[George W. Bush]]. On the BBC programme ''[[Desert Island Discs]]'' in January 2012, Johnson professed himself unimpressed by [[Nelson Mandela]].[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b019f6jt "Paul Johnson"], ''Desert Island Discs'', 15 January 2012 Johnson was appointed [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the [[2016 Birthday Honours]] for services to literature.{{London Gazette|issue=61608 |supp=y|page=B9|date=11 June 2016}} == Partial bibliography == Johnson's books are listed by subject or type. The country of publication is the UK, unless stated otherwise. === Anthologies, polemics and contemporary history === * {{Citation | last1 = Johnson | first1 = Paul Bede | year = 1957 | title = Conviction | publisher = MacGibbon & Kee | contribution = A Sense of Outrage | pages = 202–17 | first2 = Brian | last2 = Abel-Smith | first3 = Nigel | last3 = Calder | first4 = Richard | last4 = Hoggart | first5 = Mervyn | last5 = Jones | editor-first = Norman Ian | editor-last = Mackenzie | first6 = Peter | last6 = Marris | first7 = Iris | last7 = Murdoch | first8 = Peter | last8 = Shore | first9 = Hugh | last9 = Thomas | first10 = Peter | last10 = Townsend | first11 = Raymond | last11 = Williams | place = London, [[England|ENG]], [[United Kingdom|UK]]}}. * {{Citation | last = Johnson | first = Paul Bede | year = 1957 | title = The Suez War | publisher = MacGibbon & Kee | place = London, ENG, UK}}. * {{Citation | last = Johnson | first = Paul Bede | author-mask = 3 | year = 1958 | title = Journey Into Chaos | publisher = MacGibbon & Kee | series = Western Policy in the Middle East | place = London, ENG, UK}}. * {{Citation | last = Johnson | first = Paul Bede | author-mask = 3 | year = 1971 | title = Statesmen and Nations | publisher = Sidgwick & Jackson}}. {{multiple image| align = right| direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | footer = Left image: Pseudo-Kufic script on the hem of the Virgin's mantle in [[Filippo Lippi]]'s 1438 ''[[Pala Barbadori]]''. [[Louvre Museum]].
Right image: At the top, detail of the Virgin's mantle hem in [[Antonio Vivarini]]'s ''[[:File:Antonio Vivarini 1450 Saint Louis de Toulouse detail.jpg|Saint Louis de Toulouse]]'', 1450. At the bottom, detail of Virgin's mantle hem in [[Jacopo Bellini]]'s ''[[:File:Jacopo Bellini La Vierge d humilite adoree par un prince de la maison d Estee 1440 detail.jpg|Virgin of Humility]]'', 1440. [[Louvre Museum]].| footer_align = left | image1 =Filippo_Lippi_Pala_Barbadori_1437 detail.jpg| width1 = 143 | caption1 = | image2 =Pseudo Kufic examples.jpg| width2 = 245 | caption2 = }} '''Pseudo-Kufic''', or '''Kufesque''', also sometimes '''Pseudo-Arabic''', is a style of decoration used during the [[Middle Ages]] or the [[Renaissance]], consisting of imitations of the [[Arabic]] [[Kufic]] script, or sometimes Arabic cursive script, made in a non-Arabic context: "Imitations of Arabic in European art are often described as pseudo-Kufic, borrowing the term for an Arabic script that emphasizes straight and angular strokes, and is most commonly used in Islamic architectural decoration".Mack, p.51 Pseudo-Kufic appears especially often in [[Renaissance art]] in depictions of people from the [[Holy Land]], particularly the [[Virgin Mary]]. It is an example of [[Islamic influences on Western art]]. ==Early examples== [[File:Offa king of Mercia 757 793 gold dinar copy of dinar of the Abassid Caliphate 774.jpg|thumb|left|A [[mancus]] or gold [[dinar]] of the English king [[Offa]] (r. 757–796), a copy of the dinars of the [[Abbasid Caliphate]] (774). It displays the Latin legend ''Offa Rex'' ("King Offa") between the pseudo-Kufic lines.]] [[File:Pseudo Kufic script in medallion on Byzantine shroud of Saint Potentien 12th century.jpg|thumb|Pseudo-Kufic script in medallion on [[Byzantine]] [[shroud]] of Saint Potentian, 12th century.]] [[File:French ciborium with rim engraved with Arabic script and Islamic inspired diamond shaped pattern Limoges France 1215 1230.jpg|thumb|French [[Limoges enamel]] [[Ciborium (container)|ciborium]] with rim engraved with Arabic script and Islamic-inspired diamond-shaped patterns, [[Limoges]], [[France]], 1215–30. [[British Museum]].]] Some of the first imitations of the Kufic script go back to the 8th century when the English King [[Offa]] (r. 757–796) produced gold coins imitating Islamic [[dinars]]. These coins were copies of an [[Abbasid Caliphate|Abbasid]] dinar struck in 774 by Caliph [[Al-Mansur]], with "Offa Rex" centred on the reverse. It is clear that the moneyer had no understanding of [[Arabic language|Arabic]] as the Arabic text contains many errors. The coin may have been produced in order to trade with [[Al-Andalus|Islamic Spain]]; or it may be part of the annual payment of 365 [[mancus]]es that Offa promised to Rome.[https://books.google.com/books?id=TGkz9NGFXIMC&pg=PA327&dq=manqush+coin#PPA330,M1 ''Medieval European Coinage'' by Philip Grierson p.330] In Medieval southern [[Italy]] (in merchant cities such as [[Amalfi]] and [[Salerno]]) from the mid-10th century, imitations of Arabic coins, called [[tarì]], were widespread but only used illegible pseudo-Kufic script.[https://books.google.com/books?id=pePPvGkGZDQC&pg=PA26&dq=kharruba+coin&lr= Cardini, p.26]Grierson, p.3[https://books.google.com/books?id=CQfub3l_ejkC&pg=PA240&dq=Tar%C3%AC+Arabic#PPA240,M1 Matthew, p.240] Examples are known of the incorporation of Kufic script and Islamic-inspired colourful diamond-shaped designs such as a 13th French [[Limoges enamel]] [[Ciborium (container)|ciborium]] at the [[British Museum]].[[British Museum]] exhibit The band in pseudo-Kufic script "was a recurrent ornamental feature in [[Limoges]] and had long been adopted in [[Aquitaine]]".[http://www.louvre.fr/llv/oeuvres/detail_notice.jsp?CONTENT%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673226036&CURRENT_LLV_NOTICE%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673226036&FOLDER%3C%3Efolder_id=9852723696500778&bmLocale=en Louvre museum notice] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615183547/http://www.louvre.fr/llv/oeuvres/detail_notice.jsp?CONTENT%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673226036&CURRENT_LLV_NOTICE%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673226036&FOLDER%3C%3Efolder_id=9852723696500778&bmLocale=en |date=2011-06-15 }} File:Limoges enamel ciborium pseudo Kufic circa 1200.jpg|Pseudo-Kufic band in [[Limoges enamel]] [[Ciborium (container)|ciborium]], circa 1200. [[Louvre Museum]]. File:Blue and white faience albarello with designs derived from Kufic script Toscane 2nd half 15th century.jpg|[[Blue-and-white]] [[faience]] ''[[albarello]]'' with Kufic-inspired designs, [[Tuscany]], 2nd half of 15th century. ==Renaissance painting== [[File:Ugolino di Nerio 1315 1320 La Vierge et l Enfant Sienne detail.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Pseudo-Kufic on the veil of the Virgin, [[Ugolino di Nerio]], 1315–1320.]] [[File:Paolo Veneziano 1354 La Vierge et l Enfant detail.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Pseudo-Kufic mantle hem, in [[Paolo Veneziano]]'s ''Virgin Mary and Child'', 1358. [[Louvre Museum]].]] [[File:Gentile da Fabriano 015.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Pseudo-Arabic script in the [[Virgin Mary]]'s [[Halo (religious iconography)|halo]], detail of ''Adoration of the Magi'' (1423) by [[Gentile da Fabriano]]. The script is further divided by [[Rosette (design)|rosette]]s like those on [[Mamluk]] dishes.Mack, p.65-66]] Numerous instances of pseudo-Kufic are known from European art from around the 10th to the 15th century. Pseudo-Kufic inscriptions were often used as decorative bands in the architecture of [[Byzantine]] [[Greece]] from the mid 11th century to mid-12th century, and in decorative bands around religious scenes in French and German wall paintings from the mid-12th to mid-13th century, as well as in contemporary manuscript illuminations.Mack, p.68 Pseudo-Kufic would also be used as writing or as decorative elements in textiles, religious [[halos]] or frames.{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/spotlight/beautiful-gibberish-fake-arabic-in-medieval-and-renaissance-art|title=Beautiful Gibberish: Fake Arabic in Medieval and Renaissance Art|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2017-05-30|language=en}} Many are visible in the paintings of [[Giotto]] (c. 1267 – 1337). From 1300 to 1600, according to Rosamond Mack, the Italian imitations of Arabic script tend to rely on cursive Arabic rather than Kufic, and therefore should better be designated by the more generalist term of "Pseudo-Arabic". The habit of representing gilt halos decorated with pseudo-Kufic script seems to have disappeared in 1350, but was revived around 1420 with the work of painters such as [[Gentile da Fabriano]], who was probably responding to artistic influence in [[Florence]], or [[Masaccio]], who was influenced by Gentile, although his own script was "jagged and clumsy", as well as [[Giovanni Francesco Toscani|Giovanni Toscani]] or [[Fra Angelico]], in a more [[Gothic art|Gothic]] style.Mack, p.64-66 [[File:Masaccio 031.jpg|thumb|upright|Virgin Mary with pseudo-Arabic halo, by [[Masaccio]] (1426).Mack, p.66]] [[File:Gentile da Fabriano 037.jpg|thumb|upright|Pseudo-Arabic on the Christ Child's blanket. [[Gentile da Fabriano]].Mack, p.61-62]] [[File:Fra Angelico 001.jpg|thumb|upright|Virgin with a [[Gothic art|Gothicizing]] pseudo-Arabic halo, by [[Fra Angelico]] (1428–1430).]] [[File:Central panel - Pala di San Zeno by Andrea Mantegna - San Zeno - Verona 2016.jpg|thumb|upright|The Virgin Mary in [[Andrea Mantegna]]'s [[San Zeno Altarpiece (Mantegna)|San Zeno Altarpiece]] combines pseudo-Arabic halos and garment hems, with a Turkish carpet at her feet (1456–1459).]] From around 1450, northern Italian artists also started to incorporate pseudo-Islamic decorative devices in their paintings. [[Francesco Squarcione]] started the trend in 1455, and he was soon followed by his main pupil, [[Andrea Mantegna]]. In the 1456–1459 [[San Zeno Altarpiece (Mantegna)|San Zeno Altarpiece]], Mantegna combines pseudo-Islamic script in halos and garment hems ([[:File:Andrea Mantegna 025.jpg|see detail]]), to depiction of [[Mamluk]] book-bindings in the hand of San Zeno ([[:File:Andrea Mantegna 023.jpg|see detail]]), and even to a Turkish carpet at the feet of the Virgin Mary ([[:File:Andrea Mantegna 028.jpg|see detail]]).Mack, p.67 The exact reason for the incorporation of pseudo-Kufic or pseudo-Arabic in Medieval or early Renaissance painting is unclear. It seems that Westerners mistakenly associated 13-14th century Middle-Eastern scripts as being identical with the scripts current during [[Jesus]]'s time, and thus found natural to represent early Christians in association with them:Mack, p.52, p.69 "In Renaissance art, pseudo-Kufic script was used to decorate the costumes of [[Old Testament]] heroes like David".[https://books.google.com/books?id=tsiIvJ16AU0C&pg=PA84&dq=Pseudo-Kufic&as_brr=3&hl=en Freider. p.84] Another reason might be that artist wished to express a cultural universality for the Christian faith, by blending together various written languages, at a time when the church had strong international ambitions."Perhaps they marked the imagery of a universal faith, an artistic intention consistent with the Church's contemporary international program." Mack, p.69 Pseudo-Hebrew is also sometimes seen,Mack, p. 62 as in the [[mosaic]] at the back of the [[abse]] in [[Marco Marziale]]'s ''Circumcision'', which does not use actual Hebrew characters.[http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/cgi-bin/WebObjects.dll/CollectionPublisher.woa/wa/largeImage?workNumber=NG803&collectionPublisherSection=work National Gallery, image] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507202827/http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/cgi-bin/WebObjects.dll/CollectionPublisher.woa/wa/largeImage?workNumber=NG803&collectionPublisherSection=work |date=2009-05-07 }} It was especially common in German works. Finally pseudo-Arabic elements became rare after the second decade of the 16th century.Mack, p.71 According to Rosamond Mack: "The Eastern scripts, garments, and halos disappeared when the Italians viewed the Early Christian era in an antique [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] context." ==See also== {{Arab culture}} * [[Islamic contributions to Medieval Europe]] * [[Thematic development of Italian Renaissance painting]] * [[Oriental carpets in Renaissance painting]] * [[Islamic influences on Christian art]] * [[Orientalism]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * Braden K. Frieder ''Chivalry & the perfect prince: tournaments, art, and armor at the Spanish Habsburg court'' Truman State University, 2008 {{ISBN|1-931112-69-X}}, {{ISBN|978-1-931112-69-7}} * Cardini, Franco. ''Europe and Islam''. Blackwell Publishing, 2001. {{ISBN|978-0-631-22637-6}} * Grierson, Philip ''Medieval European Coinage'' Cambridge University Press, 2007 {{ISBN|0-521-03177-X}}, {{ISBN|978-0-521-03177-6}} * Mack, Rosamond E. Bazaar to Piazza: Islamic Trade and Italian Art, 1300–1600, University of California Press, 2001 {{ISBN|0-520-22131-1}} * Matthew, Donald, ''The Norman kingdom of Sicily'' Cambridge University Press, 1992 {{ISBN|978-0-521-26911-7}} ==Gallery== File:Henri Bellechose Le Retable de Saint Denis 1415 1416 detail.jpg|Pseudo-Kufic on garments in [[Henri Bellechose]]'s ''Le Retable de Saint Denis'', 1415–1416. File:Jacopo Bellini La Vierge d humilite adoree par un prince de la maison d Estee 1440 detail.jpg|''Virgin of Humility, adored by a prince of the House of Este'' by [[Jacopo Bellini]], 1440, with pseudo-Kufic mantle hem, but halo in Roman script. [[Louvre Museum]]. File:Antonio Vivarini 1450 Saint Louis de Toulouse detail.jpg|Pseudo-Kufic halo, in [[Antonio Vivarini]]'s ''[[Saint Louis de Toulouse]]'', 1450. [[Louvre Museum]]. File:Giovanni Bellini Le Christ Benissant 1465 1470 detail.jpg|Pseudo-Kufic hem in [[Giovanni Bellini]]'s ''[[:File:Giovanni Bellini Le Christ Benissant 1465 1470.jpg|Le Christ Bénissant]]'', 1465–1470. [[Louvre Museum]]. File:Early 1500 Andalusian dish with pseudo Arabic script around the edge excavated in London.jpg|Early-16th-century [[Andalusian people|Andalusian]] dish with pseudo-Arabic script around the edge, excavated in London. [[London Museum]]. ===Pseudo-Hebrew=== File:Jan van Scorel - Maria Magdalena (Rijksmuseum Amsterdam version).jpg|Pseudo-Hebrew script on the [[bustier]] of [[Jan van Scorel]]'s ''Maria Magdalena'', 1530. The '''Religion News Association (RNA)''' is a [[Non-profit organization|non-profit]] [[professional association]] in the [[United States]] which seeks to promote better reporting on [[religion]] in the [[news media]] and to provide help and support to [[journalist]]s who cover religion.<ref>[http://www.journalismtraining.org/action/provider_detail?id=502 Religion Newswriters Association] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716165529/http://www.journalismtraining.org/action/provider_detail?id=502 |date=2011-07-16 }} National Society of Professional Journalists, JournalismTraining.org. Accessed September 6, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.theledger.com/article/20080809/COLUMNISTS/808090308/1096/life Religion News Becoming Obsolete] The Ledger, August 9, 2008</ref> It was founded in 1949 and in 2007 had 570 members and subscribers.<ref>[http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2007/10/09/faith/19_59_4310_4_07.prt Dolbee, Gorski honored by Religion Newswriters Association] North County Times, October 4, 2007</ref><ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/US/WireStory?id=3689445&page=3 Religion News in Brief] [[ABC News]] Accessed September 6, 2008</ref> Membership in the RNA is open to journalists who regularly report on religion in the secular print and broadcast media.<ref>[http://www.cnjo.org/node/58 Religion Newswriters Association] [[Council of National Journalism Organizations]] Accessed September 8, 2008</ref><ref>[https://www.npr.org/about/press/2007/100307.islam.html NPR NEWS’ RACHEL MARTIN WINS RELIGION NEWSWRITERS ASSOCIATION AWARD FOR REPORT ON LATINO EXODUS FROM CATHOLICISM TO ISLAM] [[National Public Radio]] October 3, 2007</ref> Since 2006, the RNA has been associated with the [[Missouri School of Journalism]] at the [[University of Missouri]].<ref>[http://journalism.missouri.edu/news/2006/09-08-debra-mason.html Debra Mason Named Director of Center for Religion, the Professions and the Public] Missouri School of Journalism, September 8, 2006</ref> In 2016, RNA members approved a proposal to change the name from the "Religion Newswriters Association" to the current name.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rna.org/news/296851/RNA-members-vote-to-change-organizations-name-to-Religion-News-Association.htm|title=RNA members vote to change organization's name to Religion News Association - Religion News Association & Foundation|website=www.rna.org|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref>
RNA awards [[scholarships]] for full-time journalists who wish to take college courses on religion,<ref>[http://www.aaja.org/news/industry/2006_02_22_1/ Religion Newswriters Association Scholarship] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611154440/http://www.aaja.org/news/industry/2006_02_22_1/ |date=2011-06-11 }} Asian American Journalists Association, Accessed September 6, 2008</ref> gives awards and scholarships to college journalists,<ref>[http://journalism.missouri.edu/news/2004/06-17-todd.html Ross Todd Named Finalist in Religion Newswriters Association National Contest] Missouri School of Journalism, Accessed September 6, 2008</ref> sponsors seminars and conferences <ref>[http://www.fair.org/index.php?page=2692 Religion and Politics The Media's One-Dimensional View] [[Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting]] July/August 1994</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rna.org/seminarsworkshops.php |title=RNA Seminars and Workshops |access-date=2008-09-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080918032252/http://www.rna.org/seminarsworkshops.php |archive-date=2008-09-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> and publishes a "primer" for religion reporters<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.religionwriters.com/tools-resources/reporting-on-religion-a-primer-on-journalisms-best-beat |title="Reporting on Religion: A Primer on Journalism's Best Beat" |access-date=2010-07-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100810205924/http://www.religionwriters.com/tools-resources/reporting-on-religion-a-primer-on-journalisms-best-beat |archive-date=2010-08-10 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> and an online style guide,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.religionwriters.com/tools-resources/religionstylebook |title=ReligionStylebook |access-date=2010-07-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727033833/http://www.religionwriters.com/tools-resources/religionstylebook |archive-date=2010-07-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> as well as other resources for journalists. RNA is funded by membership dues, donations, and Religion News Foundation support.
In 1999, former RNA executive director Debra Mason said in an interview that the topic of religion is very complex and requires extensive research, something which newspaper [[editing|editor]]s don't always appreciate.<ref>[http://www.asne.org/reports/1999localnewshandbook/Ch9SPIRITUALITY.html The Local News Handbook] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060528161411/http://www.asne.org/reports/1999localnewshandbook/Ch9SPIRITUALITY.html |date=2006-05-28 }} 1999, The [[American Society of Newspaper Editors]]</ref> In 2005, Steve Buttry writing at [[The Poynter Institute for Media Studies|Poynter Online]] said, "The Religion Newswriters Association does a tremendous job helping reporters learn the beat."<ref>[http://www.poynter.org/content/content_view.asp?id=76751 Help Wanted on Religion Beat: Don't Limit the Talent Pool] Steve Buttry, Poynter Online, January 11, 2005</ref> RNA was cited by Kenneth G. C. Newport and Crawford Gribben in their 2006 book ''Expecting the End: Millennialism in Social and Historical Context'' for helping reporters get in touch with credentialed scholars on religion, leading to better public understanding of religious issues.<ref>''Expecting the End: Millennialism in Social and Historical Context'', Kenneth G. C. Newport, Crawford Gribben, Baylor University Press, 2006, {{ISBN|1-932792-38-4}}, {{ISBN|978-1-932792-38-6}}</ref>
Since the 1970s, RNA has published an annual list of the top ten religion-related news stories of the previous year.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/religion/stories/s1265880.htm 2004 - Year in Review] [[ABC News]] Accessed September 8, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.anglicanjournal.com/world/015/article/buddhist-monks-revolt-among-top-news-stories/ Buddhist monks’ revolt among top news stories][[Anglican Journal]] February 1, 2008</ref> In 1999, RNA was criticized by the Islamic organization the Wisdom Fund for listing a story on a special "Top 10 Stories of The Millennium" list which gave inaccurate information on the history of [[Islam]] in [[India]].<ref>[http://www.twf.org/News/Y1999/1206-NewsAssoc.html Religion Newswriters Association Bashes Islam] The Wisdom Fund, December 6, 1999</ref> In the same year, RNA also published a list of the top ten religious news stories of the Twentieth century, with the [[Holocaust]] being the most important event.<ref>[http://tmatt.gospelcom.net/column/1999/12/15/ The century -- death by "quasi-religion"] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20020822121316/http://tmatt.gospelcom.net/column/1999/12/15/ |date=2002-08-22 }} Terri Mattingly, ''On Religion''</ref>
In 2001, RNA was criticized by conservative commentator David Kupelain for its criticism of the expression "[[Islamic terrorist]]" and other expressions, of which RNA said: "similar phrases that associate an entire religion with the action of a few."<ref>[http://www.worldnetdaily.com/news/article.asp?ARTICLE_ID=24704 Politically correct terrorism] David Kupelain, [[World Net Daily]] September 28, 2001</ref> In 2006, representatives from [[the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] and the [[Church of Scientology]] spoke to the annual RNA conference and discussed issues concerning their respective faiths.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4188/is_20060910/ai_n16721913 Faiths 'that don't fit' educate journalists] [[Deseret News]] September 10, 2006</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=April 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Politics of Bangladesh}} '''Secularism''' ({{lang-bn|ধর্ম নিরপেক্ষতা}}) is one of the four fundamental principles according to the original 1972 [[Constitution of Bangladesh]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd/sections_detail.php?id=367&sections_id=24560|title=8. Secularism and freedom of religion|last=Peoples' Republic of Bangladesh|first=|publisher=[[Government of Bangladesh]]|year=1972|isbn=|location=Bangladesh|pages=|chapter=Part II – Fundamental Principles of State Policy|lay-url=|via=}}</ref> The secularism principle was removed from the constitution in 1977 by [[Ziaur Rahman]], replaced with a statement of "absolute trust and faith in Almighty Allah", and [[Islam]] was declared the state religion in 1988. In 2010, the [[Bangladesh Supreme Court]] restored secularism as one of the basic tenets of the constitution<ref name=Zeenews2010>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/south-asia/bangladesh-s-court-restores-secularism-in-constitution_644258.html|title=Bangladesh's court restores 'secularism' in Constitution|date=29 July 2010|publisher=}}</ref> but Islam remained the state religion.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd/sections_detail.php?id=367&sections_id=24560|title=2A.The state religion|last=Peoples' Republic of Bangladesh|first=|publisher=[[Government of Bangladesh]]|year=1972|isbn=|location=Bangladesh|pages=|chapter=Part I-The Republic|lay-url=|via=|}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=February 2018|reason=Nothing about Islam at source}} Over 90% of Bangladeshis are Muslims, the rest being Hindus 8%, Buddhists 1%, Christians 0.9%, and others 0.1%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.virtualbangladesh.com/bd_religion.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=10 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131116192146/http://www.virtualbangladesh.com/bd_religion.html |archivedate=16 November 2013}}{{verify credibility|date=May 2016}}</ref> People in Bangladesh observe various secular festivals at different times throughout the year. The ethos of secularism in South Asia is in many ways different from that of Western versions that assert complete [[separation of church and state]]. Rather, it is the [[Freedom of religion in Bangladesh|freedom of individuals]] to practice the faith he or she desires without being subject to any form of state or communal discrimination.
==Secularism in the Constitution== Secularism is one of the four fundamental principles that had been induced into the original [[Constitution of Bangladesh]] in 1972. The secularism principle was removed from the constitution in 1977 by the 5th amendment of the constitution by [[Ziaur Rahman]] and also declared [[Islam]] as the state religion in 1988 by [[Hussain Muhammad Ershad|Muhammad Ershad]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/bangladesh-court-rejects-challenge-to-islam-as-state-religion-1459166329|title=Bangladesh Court Rejects Challenge to Islam as State Religion|last=Al-Mahmood|first=Syed Zain|newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]]|issn=0099-9660|access-date=30 March 2016}}</ref> In 2010, [[Bangladesh Supreme Court]] declared the 5th amendment illegal and restored secularism as one of the basic tenets of the Constitution<ref name=Zeenews2010/>
At present [[The Constitution of Bangladesh]] declares Secularism as one of the four fundamental principle of the state policy in Article-8 of Part-II<ref>Part II, Article: 8, ''The Constitution of Bangladesh''</ref> and also declares Islam as the state religion in Article-2A of Part-I.<ref>Part II, Article: 2A, ''The Constitution of Bangladesh''</ref> In Article 12 of Part -II of the constitution which was restored by the 15th amendment states –
''The principle of secularism shall be realised by the elimination of -'' # ''Communalism in all forms;'' # ''the granting by the state of political status in favour of any religion;'' # ''the abuse of religion for political purposes;'' # ''any discrimination against, or persecution of, persons practising a particular religion.''"<ref>Part II, Article: 12, ''The Constitution of Bangladesh''</ref>
==Impact of constitutional changes== The removal of secularism from the constitution has been described by the country's largely secular establishment as a betrayal of [[Bengali nationalism]] and also opposed to mainstream Bengali culture and society, both of which are seen as remarkably [[Pluralism (political philosophy)|pluralist]] and [[progressivism|progressive]]. However, the [[Bangladesh Army]] with its close ideological association of centre-right and conservative political parties led by the [[Bangladesh Nationalist Party]], have stated that the term [[Bangladeshi nationalism]] refers to the country as an Islamic nation given that 89% of the population is Muslim.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bg.html#People |title=CIA – The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=23 January 2013}}</ref>
In 2008, the newly elected [[Awami League]] government announced that it would re-introduce the original Four State Principles into the Preamble of the Constitution of Bangladesh. Although recognised by the United Nations as a "moderate Muslim democracy", Bangladesh's foreign minister [[Dipu Moni]] stated that the country is, in her words, "a secular, not moderate Muslim, country".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.snnbd.com/newsdetails.php?cat_id=0.02&id=12637#.UfvNSRbZHCE|title=Bangladesh is secular, not moderate Muslim country: FM|date=12 April 2009|publisher=SNN Media Limited|accessdate=2 August 2013}}</ref>
== History == [[Image:Pohela boishakh 2.jpg|right|thumb|[[Pohela Baishakh]], a secular festival being celebrated in Dhaka]] Despite the country ceasing to be a secular state constitutionally once, secularism came back in 2010 and has been practised in the region of [[Bengal]] since ancient times.<ref>{{cite web |title = 12. Secularism and freedom of religion |url = http://bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd/sections_detail.php?id=367&sections_id=24560%257CSection |website = Legislative and Parliamentary Affairs Division |publisher = Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs |accessdate = 4 November 2015}}</ref> Ancient and medieval rulers, especially the [[Pala Empire]] and [[Nawabs of Bengal]] practised secularism in making decisions of the court. [[Hindus]] and [[Muslims]] would have prominent leaders from each community assisting the rulers. When the [[British East India Company]] came in the 18th century, it instituted separate laws for Hindus, Muslims and Christians. In doing so they laid the foundation for a civil code which remains largely unchanged to date. [[Image:BD Dance.jpg|thumb|Bangladeshi artists performing a traditional dance. Bengali culture is seen as fiercely secular.]] However, the British had perpetuated division amongst Bengali communities on the basis of [[divide and rule]]. Bengali Hindus were seen as affluent, educated and were accepted in civil services. On the other hand, [[Bengali Muslims]], especially those in [[East Bengal]] were highly discriminated. Most East Bengali Muslims were peasants and were persecuted by Hindu [[zamindars]] supported by the [[British Raj]]. This had led to several religious movements across East Bengal such as the [[Faraizi movement]] aimed at resisting the British and the Hindu zamindars class. In 1905, [[Nawab Sir Khwaja Salimullah]], the Nawab of Dhaka, proposed the [[Partition of Bengal (1905)|partition of Bengal]] on communal lines to establish a separate province for the suppressed majority of the region who live in East Bengal and were mostly Muslim. The British accepted the partition and a new province by the name of [[Eastern Bengal and Assam]] was created. However the partition was annulled in 1911 due to resistance from the [[Swadeshi]] movement in West Bengal that demanded the unification of Bengal. In 1947, Bengal would again be partitioned on communal lines with East Bengal (present day Bangladesh) joining [[Pakistan]] and [[West Bengal]] being part of [[India]] though Hindu majority district of [[Khulna]] was awarded to Pakistan and Muslim majority districts of [[Malda district|Malda]] and [[Murshidabad]] were awarded to West Bengal. Ethnic cleansing of Hindus forced many Hindus to migrate to India notably on the backdrop of [[1950 East Pakistan riots]] and [[1964 East Pakistan riots]]. After the establishment of Pakistan, Bengalis faced immense discrimination and economic suffering. The [[Bengali nationalist]] movement quickly geared momentum with the increasing cultural and linguistic nationalism that were inherently secular. The [[Bangladesh Liberation War]] would see Bengalis, irrespective of religion join the fight for their freedom. [[Image:Bayt al Mukarram.jpg|thumb|right|Baitul Mukarram ([[Dhaka]]) the National Mosque [[Bangladesh]]. The structure resembles the [[Kaaba]] in [[Mecca]]]] After achieving victory, Bangladesh's constitution, drafted in 1972, stated Four State Principles as the character of the new state. They would be Nationalism, Democracy, [[Secularism]] and Socialism. In 1975, [[Sheikh Mujibur Rahman]], the country's founding father was assassinated by junior officers in the military and martial law was declared. Mostaq Ahmed would eventually be removed by counter coups in the volatile situation and army chief and liberation war hero Lt. Gen Ziaur Rahman (known as Zia) would take over as president.
After Zia assumed the presidency, he allied himself with his one-time enemies during the liberation war, including anti-liberation leaders such as [[Shah Azizur Rahman]], Sabur Khan and Kazi Abdul Kader. The decision to ally with anti-liberation leaders was seen as necessary political strategy to counter the Awami League of the assassinated Sheikh Mujibur Rahman. Although Zia was popular for bringing stability after the volatility after 1975, he began using religion as a major factor in politics. He formed the Bangladesh Nationalist Party that professed the more Islamic "Bangladeshi nationalism" to replace the secular Bengali nationalism. The Bangladesh parliament in 1977 amended the constitution by changing the Four State Principles. The amendment caused the term "secularism" in the Permeable to be replaced with "Absolutue trust and faith in the Almighty Allah shall be the basis of all actions", and removed references to freedom of religion. Finally in 1988, the country's second military ruler Hussain Muhammad Ershad declared Islam as the [[state religion]] in Bangladesh.<ref>{{cite book |date=1989 |editor1-last=Heitzman |editor1-first=James |editor2-last=Worden |editor2-first=Robert |chapter=More Opposition Pressure |chapter-url=http://countrystudies.us/bangladesh/93.htm |title=Bangladesh: A Country Study |url=http://countrystudies.us/bangladesh/ |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=Federal Research Division, Library of Congress |pages=173}}</ref> This would be the final blow to constitutional secularism in the country. Supporters of the BNP and the military would engage in various anti minority activities particularly against the Hindu and tribal communities of the country, most notably the anti-Hindu pogroms of 1988, [[1990 Bangladesh anti-Hindu violence|1990]], [[1992 Bangladesh violence|1992]] and [[2013 Bangladesh riots|2013]] which caused widespread damage and devastation across the country. However, after the return to democracy in 1991, there have been growing calls by the country's "pro liberation forces", the largely secular civil society and freedom fighters, as well as from the young generation to re introduce secularism back into the constitution. In 2009, the Awami League government announced that it would amend the constitution and reintroduce the original Four State Principles.
===Restoration by Supreme Court=== The Fifth Amendment of the constitution was declared illegal by the High Court of Bangladesh in 2005,<ref>{{cite news |title=Special body sits today to review constitution |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=148536 |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=28 July 2010}}</ref> the government restored a constitution "in the spirit of the constitution of 1972"<ref>{{cite news |title=Constitution to get back on '72 track|url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=124640 |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=2 February 2010}}</ref> which also included secularism as one of the state principles. Nevertheless, the opening words 'bismillah-ar-rahman-ar rahim' (In the name of Allah, the Beneficent, the Merciful), that were added in 1997, remained in the constitution.<ref>{{cite news |title=The secularity of Bangladesh Constitution after 15th Amendment |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/the-secularity-of-bangladesh-constitution-after-15th-amendment/ |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=17 March 2013}}</ref> In 2010, the Supreme Court of Bangladesh upheld the 2005 High Court ruling that the Fifth Amendment to the constitution was illegal.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bangladesh is secular again: HC |url=http://www.rediff.com/news/report/bangladesh-is-secular-again-says-hc/20101005.htm |newspaper=Rediff.com }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Habib |first=Haroon |date=25 June 2011 |title=Bangladesh: restoring secular Constitution |url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/lead/bangladesh-restoring-secular-constitution/article2132333.ece |newspaper=The Hindu |type=Opinion}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=A 'secular' Bangladesh: Country's top court lifts 4-year stay on order banning religion in politics |url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/a--secular--bangladesh-country-s-top-court-lifts-4year-stay-on-order-banning-religion-in-politics/564440/ |newspaper=Indian Express}}</ref> The prime minister Sheik Hasina stated that she favours allowing religion-based political parties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Bangladeshi-Premier-to-keep-Islam-as-state-religion-21781.html|title=BANGLADESH Bangladeshi Premier to keep Islam as state religion|first=|last=AsiaNews.it|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Petition in High court === After the Eighth Amendment of the constitution on 7 June 1988, 15 personalities had filed a public interest litigation challenging the provision of state religion.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bangladesh court rejects petition to scrap Islam as state religion |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/world/neighbours/280316/bangladesh-court-rejects-petition-to-scrap-islam-as-state-religion.html |newspaper=[[Deccan Chronicle]] |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=28 March 2016 |access-date=28 March 2016}}</ref> On 1 August 2015, a Supreme Court lawyer named Samendra Nath Goswami filed another petition with the High Court challenging the legality of the constitutional provision of Islam as the state religion despite revival of "secularism" as a fundamental state policy under a 2011 amendment to the Constitution.<ref>{{cite news |title=Islam to stay state religion |url=http://en.prothom-alo.com/bangladesh/news/99575/Islam-to-stay-state-religion-in-constitution |newspaper=[[Prothom Alo]] |date=28 March 2016 |access-date=28 March 2016}}</ref> On 28 March 2016, the high court rejected the petition and retained Islam as the state religion.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bangladesh court rejects scrapping Islam as state faith |url=https://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/World/2016/Mar-28/344349-bangladesh-court-rejects-scrapping-islam-as-state-faith.ashx |website=The Daily Star Newspaper – Lebanon |access-date=28 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Writ challenging Islam as state religion rejected |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/city/islam-retains-status-state-religion-1200808 |date=28 March 2016 |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|''The Daily Star'']] |access-date=28 March 2016}}</ref>
